Entry and exit are not free in the market

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the **Managerial Economics** exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- ## **Core Topics & Key Concepts** ### **1. Market Structures** #### **A. Monopolistic Competition** - **Definition**: Many firms selling **differentiated products** (highly but not perfectly substitutable). - **Key Features**: - Free entry/exit (no barriers). - Firms have **some price-setting power** (downward-sloping demand curve). - **Zero economic profit in long run** (due to free entry). - **Contrast with Monopoly/Oligopoly**: - Monopoly: Single seller, high barriers. - Oligopoly: Few sellers, interdependence. #### **B. Monopoly** - **Profit Maximization**: - **Condition**: \( MR = MC \). - **Demand Curve**: Monopolist operates in the **elastic region** (to maximize revenue). - **Lerner Index**: Measures monopoly power: \[ L = \frac{P - MC}{P} \] - **First-Degree Price Discrimination**: - Charging each consumer their **reservation price** (max willingness to pay). - **Third-Degree Price Discrimination**: - Charging different prices to **different consumer groups** (e.g., students vs. adults). #### **C. Common Resources** - **Definition**: Goods that are **rivalrous** (consumption by one reduces availability) but **non-excludable** (hard to prevent access). - **Examples**: Fish stocks, groundwater. - **Tragedy of the Commons**: Overuse due to lack of property rights. --- ### **2. Production & Cost Theory** #### **A. Production Functions** - **Linear Production Function**: - \( Q = aL + bK \) (constant trade-off between inputs). - Example: 3 units of labor = 1 unit of capital (from Q3). - **Cobb-Douglas**: \( Q = AL^\alpha K^\beta \) (not relevant here). - **Leontief**: Fixed input ratios (not applicable in Q3). #### **B. Cost Curves** - **Marginal Cost (MC)**: Cost of producing one more unit. - **Average Cost (AC)**: Total cost divided by quantity. - **Relationship**: \( MC \) intersects \( AC \) at its minimum. --- ### **3. Game Theory & Asymmetric Information** #### **A. Adverse Selection** - **Definition**: Market failure due to **hidden information** (e.g., high-risk individuals more likely to buy insurance). - **Example**: Risky drivers buying life insurance (Q7). #### **B. Screening vs. Signaling** - **Screening**: Action by the **uninformed party** (e.g., insurance companies checking driving records). - **Signaling**: Action by the **informed party** (e.g., education signaling productivity). - **Q8 Insight**: If bad drivers avoid tickets, insurers **cannot screen** effectively. --- ### **4. Consumer & Producer Surplus** #### **A. Consumer Surplus (CS)** - **Definition**: Difference between what consumers **are willing to pay** and what they **actually pay**. - **Formula**: \[ CS = \frac{1}{2} \times (P_{\text{max}} - P_{\text{market}}) \times Q \] - **Example**: From Q9–Q11 (monopoly case). #### **B. Producer Surplus (PS)** - **Definition**: Difference between what producers **receive** and their **cost**. - **Formula**: \[ PS = \frac{1}{2} \times (P_{\text{market}} - MC) \times Q \] #### **C. Deadweight Loss (DWL)** - **Definition**: Loss in economic efficiency due to market distortions (e.g., monopoly, tariffs). - **Formula**: \[ DWL = \frac{1}{2} \times (P - MC) \times (Q_{\text{competitive}} - Q_{\text{monopoly}}) \] --- ### **5. Risk Preferences & Utility** #### **A. Risk Aversion** - **Definition**: Preference for **certainty** over gambles with equal expected value. - **Utility Function**: \( u(I) = \sqrt{10I} \) (from Q12–Q14). - **Expected Utility (EU)**: \[ EU = \sum p_i \times u(I_i) \] - **Certainty Equivalent (CE)**: Amount of certain income that gives the same utility as a gamble. - **Risk Premium**: \( CE - \text{Expected Value} \). #### **B. Insurance** - **Willingness to Pay**: Difference between **expected utility** and **utility of certain income**. - **Example**: Nita’s insurance premium (Q14). --- ### **6. Tariffs & International Trade** #### **A. Tariff Effects** - **Consumer Price**: Increases by tariff amount (if small country) or less (if large country). - **Quantity Demanded**: Falls due to higher price. - **Consumer Surplus Loss**: Area between old and new price on demand curve. - **Government Revenue**: Tariff × New quantity. - **Deadweight Loss**: Net loss to society (from Q15–Q20). #### **B. Key Equations (Palm Oil Example)** - **Demand**: \( Q = 2500 - 2P \). - **Supply (with tariff)**: \( P = MC + \text{Tariff} = 125 + 25 = 150 \). - **New Quantity**: \( Q = 2500 - 2(150) = 2200 \). --- ### **7. Externalities & Market Failure** #### **A. Negative Externalities** - **Definition**: Costs borne by **third parties** (e.g., pollution). - **Marginal External Cost (MEC)**: Additional cost to society per unit. - **Socially Efficient Output**: Where \( P = MC + MEC \). #### **B. Pigovian Tax** - **Purpose**: Internalize the externality. - **Tax Amount**: Equal to \( MEC \) at efficient output (from Q21–Q25). --- ### **8. Monopoly vs. Competition** #### **A. Competitive Market** - **Output**: \( P = MC \). - **Example (Dry Cleaning)**: - Demand: \( P = 100 - Q \). - \( MC = 10 + Q \). - Equilibrium: \( 100 - Q = 10 + Q \Rightarrow Q = 45 \). #### **B. Monopoly** - **Output**: \( MR = MC \). - **Example (Dry Cleaning)**: - \( TR = P \times Q = (100 - Q)Q \). - \( MR = 100 - 2Q \). - Set \( MR = MC \): \( 100 - 2Q = 10 + Q \Rightarrow Q = 30 \). --- ### **9. Price Discrimination (Airlines)** #### **A. Third-Degree Price Discrimination** - **Segments**: Business (less elastic) vs. Students (more elastic). - **Pricing Rule**: \[ \frac{P_A - MC}{P_A} = \frac{1}{|\epsilon_A|}, \quad \frac{P_B - MC}{P_B} = \frac{1}{|\epsilon_B|} \] - **Example (BA Airlines)**: - Business demand: \( Q_A = 260 - 0.4P \). - Student demand: \( Q_B = 240 - 0.6P \). - \( MC = 100 \). --- ## **Key Equations Summary** | **Concept** | **Equation** | |---------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Profit Maximization** | \( MR = MC \) | | **Monopoly Revenue** | \( TR = P \times Q \), \( MR = \frac{d(TR)}{dQ} \) | | **Lerner Index** | \( L = \frac{P - MC}{P} \) | | **Consumer Surplus** | \( CS = \frac{1}{2} \times (P_{\text{max}} - P) \times Q \) | | **Producer Surplus** | \( PS = \frac{1}{2} \times (P - MC) \times Q \) | | **Deadweight Loss** | \( DWL = \frac{1}{2} \times (P - MC) \times \Delta Q \) | | **Expected Utility** | \( EU = \sum p_i \times u(I_i) \) | | **Risk Premium** | \( RP = \text{Expected Value} - \text{Certainty Equivalent} \) | | **Tariff Impact** | \( P_{\text{new}} = P_{\text{world}} + \text{Tariff} \) | | **Social Cost** | \( SC = MC + MEC \) | | **Pigovian Tax** | \( t = MEC \) | | **Price Discrimination** | \( \frac{P - MC}{P} = \frac{1}{|\epsilon|} \) | --- ## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** ### **1. Market Structures** ```mermaid graph TD A[Market Structures] --> B[Perfect Competition] A --> C[Monopolistic Competition] A --> D[Oligopoly] A --> E[Monopoly] B -->|Features| F[Price Taker
Zero Profit
No Barriers] C -->|Features| G[Differentiated Products
Free Entry
Some Price Power] D -->|Features| H[Few Firms
Interdependence
Barriers to Entry] E -->|Features| I[Single Seller
High Barriers
Price Maker] C --> J[Advertising
Branding] E --> K[Profit Maximization: MR=MC
Lerner Index] ``` ### **2. Production & Cost Theory** ```mermaid graph TD A[Production Theory] --> B[Production Function] B --> C[Linear: Q = aL + bK] B --> D[Cobb-Douglas] B --> E[Leontief] A --> F[Cost Curves] F --> G[Marginal Cost] F --> H[Average Cost] F --> I[Total Cost] G -->|Relationship| J[MC intersects AC at minimum] ``` ### **3. Asymmetric Information** ```mermaid graph TD A[Asymmetric Information] --> B[Adverse Selection] A --> C[Moral Hazard] B -->|Example| D[High-risk individuals buy insurance] B --> E[Lemons Problem in Used Cars] C -->|Example| F[Insured take more risks] C --> G[Hidden Action] A --> H[Solutions] H --> I[Screening] H --> J[Signaling] H --> K[Government Regulation] ``` ### **4. Monopoly & Price Discrimination** ```mermaid graph TD A[Monopoly] --> B[Profit Maximization: MR=MC] A --> C[Market Power] C --> D[Lerner Index: (P-MC)/P] A --> E[Price Discrimination] E --> F[1st Degree: Perfect] E --> G[2nd Degree: Quantity Discounts] E --> H[3rd Degree: Segment Pricing] H -->|Example| I[Business vs. Students] H -->|Rule| J[P - MC / P = 1/|elasticity|] ``` ### **5. Tariffs & Trade** ```mermaid graph TD A[Tariffs] --> B[Effects] B --> C[Higher Consumer Price] B --> D[Lower Quantity Demanded] B --> E[Government Revenue] A --> F[Welfare Analysis] F --> G[Consumer Surplus Loss] F --> H[Producer Surplus Gain] F --> I[Deadweight Loss] A --> J[Small vs. Large Country] J --> K[Small: Full tariff passed to consumers] J --> L[Large: Terms of trade effect] ``` ### **6. Externalities & Market Failure** ```mermaid graph TD A[Externalities] --> B[Negative: Pollution] A --> C[Positive: Education] B --> D[Marginal External Cost] B --> E[Social Cost = Private Cost + MEC] A --> F[Solutions] F --> G[Pigovian Tax] F --> H[Cap-and-Trade] F --> I[Coase Theorem] ``` ### **7. Risk & Utility** ```mermaid graph TD A[Risk Preferences] --> B[Risk Averse] A --> C[Risk Neutral] A --> D[Risk Loving] B --> E[Utility Function: Concave] B --> F[Buys Insurance] A --> G[Expected Utility] G --> H[EU = Σ p_i * u(I_i)] A --> I[Certainty Equivalent] A --> J[Risk Premium] ``` ### **8. Game Theory (Adverse Selection)** ```mermaid graph TD A[Adverse Selection] --> B[Hidden Information] B --> C[Insurance Markets] B --> D[Used Cars] A --> E[Solutions] E --> F[Screening: Insurer checks records] E --> G[Signaling: Education, warranties] E --> H[Government Intervention] ``` --- ## **Exam Strategy** 1. **Monopoly Problems**: - Always start with \( MR = MC \). - Calculate \( TR = P \times Q \), then derive \( MR \). - Use the Lerner Index for monopoly power. 2. **Tariffs/Trade**: - Find the new price (\( P = MC + \text{Tariff} \)). - Calculate new quantity, CS, PS, DWL. 3. **Risk & Utility**: - Compute expected utility for both options. - Compare with current utility to decide. 4. **Externalities**: - Set \( P = MC + MEC \) for social efficiency. - Pigovian tax = \( MEC \) at efficient output. 5. **Price Discrimination**: - For 3rd degree, use the inverse elasticity rule. - Separate markets by elasticity.
